data.title: Meet Gus Johnson, tonight's surprise Cowboys running back: 'Contact is something I kind of like'
data.meta_description: Meet Gus Johnson, tonight's surprise Cowboys running back: 'Contact is something I kind of like'
data.text:
Gus Johnson was hungry after working out at the Athletic Performance Lab in Katy. He hopped into a car with his agent to go eat.

His agent took a call on the way to Pappasito's. The Cowboys wanted Johnson to join them in training camp. The charter for Oxnard was leaving in two days.

The running back from Stephen F. Austin had no idea what was happening as he sat in the passenger seat.

"I really wasn't paying attention,'' Johnson said. "I'm a young kid, so anytime I can be on my phone, my head's down in my phone.

"I was just sitting there probably on Twitter. I don't know. Instagram. That's when he told me. I was just shocked.''

Even more shocking is that Johnson is likely to find himself in the starting backfield later this evening when the Cowboys open the preseason against the San Diego Chargers.

"It's big, you know,'' Johnson said. "All eyes are going to be on the preseason games to see who can play, who can't play.''

Johnson gets this opportunity because injuries to Darren McFadden and Lance Dunbar have given him more carries in practice. With Joseph Randle nursing a slight oblique strain from three days ago, the door is open for Johnson to start.

The 5-foot-10, 215-pound back is a physical runner who has done some nice things in practice. He's clearly ahead of former Baylor back Lache Seastrunk at this stage.

"I like to get the dirty yards, put my head down, not afraid of contact,'' Johnson said. "I've always been a bigger kid so contact is something I kind of like.''

Tonight is his big chance. What does offensive coordinator Scott Linehan think of Johnson and Seastrunk?

"Johnson a big back,'' Linehan said. "He seems like a guy in obvious running situations that might be something he can hang his hat on. But we'll see.

"It's a bigger change from a run style or system for Seastrunk, but he's learning.''
